courses.name: Laboratory Animal Science - Felasa Level C

profile_positions.location: Radiotherapy and OncoImmunology lab, Department of Radiation Oncology
profile_positions.description:
During my PhD I focused on improving the treatment efficacy of head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCC). This project consisted of three main lines of research: 
1) Combination of CDK4/6 inhibitors with irradiation. So far we have demonstrated that CDK4/6 inhibition greatly radiosensitises HPV negative HNSCC cells, due to an impaired DNA damage repair capacity.
2) Applying targeted sequencing of metabolic transcripts to identify metabolic genes that influence the sensitivity to irradiation.
3) Using AKT inhibitors to induce cell death in hypoxic cells. In the end we hope to gain a better understanding of intracellular mechanisms of radioresistance, as well as gain an understanding how the tumour micoenvironment affects cell death.
profile_positions.title: PhD Student

profile_positions.description: The introduction group committee of Dito is charged with organising and supervising talking groups for the LGBT students and young adult community in Nijmegen. These groups aim to increase self-acceptance among the participants and to offer them a place to share their experiences. I coordinated this committee and was a counselor of two introduction groups. Furthermore, I helped organise training days and training weekends to increase the expertise of the committee.
profile_positions.title: Coordinator/member Introduction Group Committee

profile_positions.company: Oxford Institute for Radiation Oncology, University of Oxford
profile_positions.description: Collaborated on a project involving radiosensitization of hypoxic tumour cells by targeting the DNA damage response. The project was supervised by Dr. Katarzyna Leszczynska and Dr. Ester Hammond.
profile_positions.title: Master Internship

profile_positions.description: As the student member of the MMD Education Management Team of the research Master Molecular Mechanisms of Disease, I represented the student population of the 2013-2015 cohort. During this time, I evaluated the content of the MMD courses and organisational aspects of the courses every three weeks.
profile_positions.title: Member of the Education Management Team (OMT-4) of the MMD master

company.name: Radboud Institute for Molecular Life Sciences (RIMLS)

profile_positions.company: Radboud Institute for Molecular Life Sciences (RIMLS)
profile_positions.description: As a member of the Osmoregulation group at the department of Physiology, I focused on the cellular mechanisms of lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus with a special focus on proliferation and aerobic glycolysis. This project was supervised by Prof. P. Deen and Drs. M. Alsady.
profile_positions.title: Master Internship

profile_positions.description: Under supervision of Professor B. Wouters and his research associate Dr. R. Vellanki, we worked on a project to investigate the importance of ADPGK for the tumour's ability to adapt to hypoxic conditions and its role in the metabolism of hypoxic tumours.
profile_positions.title: Bachelor Internship

profile_positions.description: In addition to my regular programme as a third year Biomedical Sciences student, I spent approximately 8 hours/week at the Department of Radiation Oncology as an intern. Under the supervision of Dr. P. Span and Dr. J. Bussink, I acquired the basic skills in the most commonly used techniques in molecular biology. Furthermore, I studied the molecular basis of the tumour's ability to adapt to low oxygen tensions (hypoxia) in the tumour microenvironment, the HIF1a pathway and the unfolded protein response (UPR) being of particular interest.
profile_positions.title: Internship
